awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A Cloud-Based Development Framework and Tool Suite for Quantum Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will to enable inexpensive access to quantum computing (QC) and to take the complexity out of the programming and application hosting tasks, which currently pose a major barrier to entry for potential users. QC technology is expected to disrupt significant portions of the high-performance computing environment for optimization problems, which has previously been characterized by slow and incremental performance improvements. This project would yield a platform that both increases the efficiency and lowers the cost of analyzing complex optimization problems, which could spur fast-paced innovation in wide areas of the economy that tackle such issues. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project addresses the need for a cloud-based platform for using QC technology. Early-generation quantum computers have been introduced by multiple hardware vendors. Despite advances in performance of QC processors, little effort has been directed toward developing programming environments and applications that can provide simple and inexpensive access to QC capabilities and that can exploit the power that QC systems will have in the near future. This project will develop a suite of front-end and back-end tools that efficiently transform high-level computing problems into formulations for circuit-model QC systems, abstracting away the physical low-level details and domain knowledge currently necessary to build QC applications. The project will further develop a set of applications in optimization, search, and machine learning. The proposed research will explore the best software tools and platform methods for integrating emerging QC capabilities into enterprise and research workflows by streamlining and making affordable the decomposition and formulation of real-world problems into implementations that run on quantum processors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this Phase II SBIR award was to research and develop cloud-based software infrastructure and algorithm libraries to provide a platform-as-a-service for quantum computing. While quantum computers promise dramatic improvements in computational performance for many problems, inventing the right quantum algorithms and software are equally important in making this promise a reality.  The specific activities of this research focused on implementing circuit-model optimization algorithms on multiple quantum computing hardware in the first year, and in the second year focused on implementing the optimization algorithms on a additional hardware platforms while also implementing quantum machine learning algorithms.   Additionally, a Phase IIB supplemental award focused on developing algorithms specifically for near-term, noisy quantum computers.  The QC Ware platform, called forge, was released on 25 September 2019 to customers and to the general public, and a significant update to the platform was released on 25 July 2020.

The first year of this project successfully adapted the quantum approximate optimization algorithm and implemented it on application programming interfaces for several quantum computing hardware technologies based on superconducting flux qubits and trapped ion qubits.  QC Ware has successfully tested new algorithms on early prototypes of these quantum computers. The hardware technology to implement the delicate quantum interactions for quantum computation is still in its early stages of development and performance is limited.  Hence, a major emphasis of this research was to develop quantum algorithms that could exploit even these early and near-term quantum computer prototypes.

QC Ware also completed the second-year tasks for the Phase II and for the Phase IIB projects. For the Phase II project, QC Ware has completed the assessment of candidate quantum machine learning algorithms and implemented the most promising into our forge platform. For the Phase IIB supplemental project, which focuses specifically on noisy, intermediate-scale quantum computers that are available now through the next 5-10 years, QC Ware has assessed quantum machine learning algorithms and the variational quantum eigensolver algorithm designed to take advantage of these early, noisy quantum computer prototypes. To enable implementation of our various algorithms across the diverse hardware applications, QC Ware evolved a circuit-model programming framework called quasar. QC Ware has begun implementing several of these algorithms and the quasar framework into our forge platform-as-a-service.

QC Ware has worked closely with QC hardware vendors in integrating our algorithms into their application programming interfaces.  In this early stage, there is a lot of discovery and development in how to best implement quantum algorithms, and QC Ware has contributed to this growing base of knowledge in the field. And through the use of our platform-as-a-service in proof-of-concept studies in industry, we are helping to build a quantum workforce.

The results from the research and development directly impact QC Ware's commercial activity.  Commercial customers have begun using forge to explore the potential of quantum computing for their own applications. QC Ware includes access to forge as part of proof-of-concept study contracts, and customers have also begun to subscribe to the forge platform outside of the proof-of-concept study projects.  QC Ware has been exposing our early research results through our QC platform to commercial enterprises in aerospace, automotive, finance, energy, and other industries, helping them to learn first-hand the promise and challenge of this new technology. 

The results have been communicated to the quantum computing community through our networking activity to commercial customers via use-case study contracts, to QC hardware vendors via public announcements on our web site (qcware.com), and will be further communicated at the annual Quantum Computing for Business conference that QC Ware established in 2017 and continues to organize and host. See the conference website (q2b.us) for more information.

The forge platform is also available to the general public (forge.qcware.com), initially with a one-month free access trial period, and then through subscription service, allowing the broader community of computing experts, amateurs, educators, and students to begin exploring and developing quantum algorithms for real-world applications.

 


Last Modified: 09/22/2020
Modified by: Randall Correll

    QCWare-Forge-Cloud-Platform
  • Figure 2 is taken from the final report of this NSF funded research, showing an example of running QC Ware's Q-Means clustering algorithm on QC Ware's forge platform, using randomly created data and a classical simulation of a quantum computer.
    QC Ware
    Copyrighted
    Randall Correll
    Quantum machine learning on QC Ware's forge platform
  • The picture shows a QC Ware quantum engineer engaging with industry collaborators to explore applications for commercial use. Many of the tools developed in this research are now used in these industrial collaborations.
    QC Ware
    Copyrighted
    Randall Correll
    QC Ware and industry collaboration
